origin: Middle English (denoting a log or tree stump): from Old French bloc (noun), bloquer (verb), from Middle Dutch blok, of unknown ultimate origin.

definitions.definition: A large solid piece of hard material, especially rock, stone, or wood, typically with flat surfaces on each side.
A large single building subdivided into separate rooms, apartments, or offices.
A large quantity or allocation of things regarded as a unit.
An obstacle to the normal progress or functioning of something.
definitions.example: substantial demands for time off may constitute a block to career advancement

definitions.definition: A flat area of something, especially a solid area of color.
definitions.example: cover the eyelid with a neutral block of color

definitions.definition: A pulley or system of pulleys mounted in a case.
Make the movement or flow in (a passage, pipe, road, etc.) difficult or impossible.
definitions.example: block up the holes with sticky tape

definitions.definition: Impress text or a design on (a book cover).
definitions.example: Original blue cloth, spine lettered and blocked in gold.

definitions.definition: Shape or reshape (a hat) using a wooden mold.
definitions.example: nobody cleans and blocks old felt hats any more

definitions.definition: Design or plan the movements of actors on a stage or movie set.
definitions.example: The stage version clearly needs blocking as there is a limited space on which to do the entire show.
